> From: Kris Henderson [mailto:khenderson@...] 
> > From: Michael Silverstein [mailto:msilverstein@...]
>
> > Here's an example of what I mean:
> > 
> > Let's assume we have class MyClass that implements interface 
> > MyInterface, with methods: public int x(){
> >   // return an answer based on y() and z() 
> > }
> > private int y() {...}
> > private int z() {...}
> > 
> > And Interface MyInterface with method:
> > public int x()
> 
> 
> In your example, shouldn't y() and z() be protected instead 
> of public or private?  This way clients can still override 
> y() and z(), and call them from the subclass, but they can 
> not be invoked from outside the class.
> 
> Keeping this on topic, the protected methods shouldn't be 
> very difficult to test.  The test can create a MockMyClass 
> that overrides y() and z() but change the modifier from 
> protected to public.

Yes, making the methods protected instead of public would work for
subclassing. I didn't mention that because in order to write tests that
live in a different package you'd have to wrap the methods as you
showed, which adds additional, and what I would consider unnecessary,
infrastructure.

I guess for me the test for the utility of access protection is that in
all the years and thousands of lines of Smalltalk code I've written I've
wished for a number of things to be added to the language, but member
access protection was never one of them and it certainly doesn't make
testing any easier.
